item.title: Introductory Real Analysis and Topology Notes
item.description: Simply notes from an oly guy. Metric Spaces A metric space is defined like groups are, over some set of points \(M\) and some distance function \(d\) called a metric. Formally \(d: M \times M \mapsto \mathbb{R}_{\geq 0}\) Any metric space has the following conditions for \(x,y,z\in M\): \(d(x,y) \geq 0\) with equality at \(x=y\) \(d(x,y) = d(y,x)\) \(d(x,y) \leq d(x,z) + d(z,y)\), so the triangle inequality holds. Note that this is enough to imply that \(d\) is a continuous function in \(M\) by using the triangle inequality â€˜on a line.
